page.title: 02Barby - Local History
page.content: Place Names - One theory is that Barby was a Saxon settlement and that the name Barby means "village on the hill". Barby is mentioned in the Domesday Book and was referred to as BERCHEBI, and was part of the Alwardsley or Fawsley Hundred. Lost Mediaeval Villages - The sites remain of two lost villages. Onley was wiped out by the Â£Black Death". A largish mound exists which is said to be a mass grave. Other bumps and dips show the existence of walls and pathways. The church bell is now installed at St. Mary's Church, Barby. Little is known about Sawcliff, it may have died out after the Enclosure Acts. Cultivation Remains - Prior to the Enclosure Act of 1778 three large fields enclosed the village. Wood Field to the West, Brackleydale to the East and Nether Field to the North.
